results.title: Delia Smith's summer collection
results.brief_description: The essence of summer is encapsulated into a sunny collection of recipes from Delia Smith, using the produce of the summer months. “Green leaves and gooseberries” shows fresh ways with herbs, salads and gooseberries. “All the world loves an icecream” introduces some unusual but delicious icecreams. “Summer fish and shellfish” shows new ways with prawns, trout, skate and crab. “A Holiday at home” demonstrates the foods of Greece, Italy and Spain and in “Food al fresco” Delia continues the holiday themes by cooking American and Eastern barbecue dishes as well as a traditional English afternoon tea. In the second volume of this series “Bright meals for sunny days” discusses curries and other spicy dishes, “A Fruitful summer” deals with fruits such as redcurrants, strawberries, peaches and raspberries, “A Vegetarian summer” deals with goat’s cheese, vegetables and home-made pizza and finally in “The Summer kitchen garden” we are shown how to preserve the tastes of summer in jams, pickles, pesto.

results.title: Painters painting (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Emile de Antonio, Mary Lampson and Turin Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This is a film about the postwar New York art scene featuring interviews with de Kooning, Rauschenberg, Stella, Poons, Johns, Motherwell, Warhol and others. It was a scene that de Antonio knew intimately. In line with his oeuvre, de Antonio saw this film as political. It was made with enthusiasm for the artists and their art but also with an awareness of the contradictions: commodification involving a network of two or three thousand people - the painters, the collectors, the owners and the dealers - although this is no more than implicit in the film.

results.title: Painters of Quebec
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree, Graham McInnes and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents seven painters of Quebec: Suzor Cote, Clarence Gagnon, Marc-Aurele Fortin, Jean-Paul Lemieux, Alfred Pellan, Henri Masson and Andre Beiler. Narrated by Marius Barbeau.

results.title: Deep threat = Mer mere
results.creator_credit: Don Arioli, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Humour helps bring home a serious point in this animated, wordless film. The sea has its own laws and man is accountable to them. Man is shown evolving from the sea, then developing industry and the wastes that pollute that same sea. (Awards: Toulon, San Antonio)

results.title: Paddle to the sea
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A children’s odyssey, from the story by Holling C. Holling. A film about a little Indian in a canoe, hand-carved in the northern forest and, in the spring, launched towards the sea. There are many adventures, all photographed with great patience and an eye for the beauty of living things. The film gives vivid impressions of Canada’s varied landscape and the life of its waterways. Commentary by Stanley Jackson. Awards: ten awards including Philadelphia; Oscar nomination, Hollywood.

results.title: Deep sea drilling project
results.creator_credit: Jack Robinson and National Science Foundation
results.brief_description: Shows how ocean bottom cores are obtained and what they tell about the drifting of continents throughout the ages. Documents the voyages of the Clomar Challenger, a new class of drilling ship able to probe deep beneath the floors of the oceans.

results.title: OZeCULTURE
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Oz shorts. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Anna Johnson, Anne Pratten, Michael Bates, Stuart McDonald, Alison Wotherspoon, Roslyn Walker, AFTRS, Angara, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Hellhole, Motion Art, Much Ado and Puppet Company
results.brief_description: The second part of an innovative and dazzling selection of Australian short films from the 1990s. The films are: “Mr. Electric” (Dir: Stuart McDonald) - in 1953 an Aboriginal man (Ernie Dingo) returns to the country home of his adopted white family to give them the gift of electricity; “Rhino” (Anna Johnson) - a kinetic black and white film combining animation and live action; “Terra Nullius” (Anne Pratten) - a confronting and disturbing film about a young Aboriginal woman dealing with her history as a survivor of incest by her adopted father; “A Passion Play” (Tony Twigg) - a haunting animated film that utilises symbols and paintings to reflect on the nature of communication; “Secrets of the City” (Cathy Linsley) - an animated dream; “Etcetera in Paper Jam” (Michael Bates) - a hilarious short about a photo- copier that turns on humans. Anyone who has worked in an office environment will enjoy this witty attack on “office culture”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anna Johnson, Anne Pratten, Michael Bates, Stuart McDonald, Alison Wotherspoon, Roslyn Walker, AFTRS, Angara, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Hellhole, Motion Art, Much Ado and Puppet Company
